<Link id="l02608" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2608"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Atomic operations such as lr.w, sc.w, and amo&#42;.w accept a &quot;memory operand&quot;</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02609" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2609"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// as one of their register operands, such as &#96;(a0)&#96;. This just denotes that</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02610" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2610"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// the register (in this case &#96;a0&#96;) contains a memory address.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02611" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2611"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02612" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2612"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Normally, we would be able to parse these by putting the parens into the</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02613" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2613"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// instruction string. However, GNU as also accepts a zero-offset memory</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02614" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2614"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// operand (such as &#96;0(a0)&#96;), and ignores the 0 Normally this would be parsed</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02615" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2615"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// with parseImmediate followed by parseMemOpBaseReg, but these instructions</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02616" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2616"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// do not accept an immediate operand, and we do not want to add a &quot;dummy&quot;</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02617" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2617"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// operand that is silently dropped.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02618" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2618"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02619" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2619"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Instead, we use this custom parser. This will: allow (and discard) an</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
